moves.1. d4 d6 2. Nf3 Nd7: Computer recommends 2..g6 leading to a likely King's Indian.  But this choice looked fine to me, because it was mainly a lesser used "Old Indian" formation.  It forced me to consider choices other than the analyzed-to-death King's Indian.
moves.3. c4 c6 4. Nc3 Ngf6 5. Qc2 e5: This is a good basic counter, especially when supported by the later ...Qc7.  It forces white to time the coming center pawn exchange exactly.
moves.6. Bg5 Be7 7. Rd1 Qc7 8. e3 O-O 9. Bd3 R: Freeing the Queen's bishop and fortifying the King-side pawns.
moves.11. h3 Ne6: But here I expected 11...Ng6 and then I would play either 12. Nh4 (following Del Solar-Jimenez Rojas, Santiago 1951) or 12. a3 (following Sasikiran-Gukasian, Canarias en Red prel. 3rd, from 2004), each with a slight positional edge. But this choice by Black looks like an invitation to pick off the h-pawn, which I accept.
moves.12. Bxf6 Bxf6 13. Bxh7+ Kh8 14. dxe5 dxe: My King's bishop is still safe, because 15...Kxh7? leads to a quick mate starting with 16. Nxf6+.
moves.15... Be7 16. c5 g6: Black finally traps the bishop, but at the cost of a fractured King-side and exposed king.  If instead 16...Nxc5, then 17. Nxc5 Bxc5 18. Ng5, threatening 19. Bg8 and 20. Qh7+.
moves.17. Nd6 Bxd6: Computer rates this move as a mistake, and recommends 17...Rd8 18. Bxg6 fxg6 19. Qxg6 Bxd6 20. Rxd6 Qg7 21. Qh5+ Kg8 22. Nxe5 Rxd6 23. cxd6 Bd7 24. Re1 Nc5 25. Nxd7 Nxd7 with a guarantee of trouble from that passed d-pawn.  If he had played instead 17...Kxh7, I was planning 18. Nxe5 Bxd6 19. cxd6 Qa5 20. d7 Bxd7 21. Nxd7.
moves.18. cxd6 Qd8 19. Bxg6 fxg6 20. Nxe5 Qf6: It was better to try 22...Rd8 in order to oppose the White rook infiltration into Black's second rank.
moves.23. Rxd7+ Kg8 24. Rfd1 Rad8 25. Ne5: Another knight move, this time to deflect the Black queen from its vital role in defending the second rank.
moves.25... Rxd7 26. Rxd7 Re7: If instead 26...Qxe5, then 27. Qh7+ ends it quickly.
moves.27. Rxe7: I should probably have played 27. Ng4 to get the knight into a better attack mode.
moves.27... Qxe7 28. Qg6+ Kf8 29. Ng4 Qf7: It is better for Black to keep the queens on the board, since the queen trade introduces a knight and pawn ending that heavily favors White.  However, I see no particular improvement Black can make here.
moves.30. Qxf7+ Kxf7 31. f4: Starting a massive King-side pawn storm.  For anyone who belittles the power of the pawn, this ending can be educational.
moves.31... Nc5 32. Ne5+: The e5 square is an excellent base for the White knight, because it can now support the pawn roller as it moves into the King-side corner.
moves.32... Ke6 33. g4 Ne4: There are few choices for the Black knight.  It can only wait.  Any foray it makes into White's Queen-side leaves the Black king with no defense.
moves.34. h4 Kf6 35. Kg2 Nd6 36. h5 Ne4: The only choice here for Black is 36...Kg7, to slow the advancing h-pawn and look for a chance to blockade the pawn roller.  But these four connected passed pawns are a terror for Black in this game.
moves.37. h6 Nd6 38. g5+: Forcing the black king away from the square of the h-pawn.  Now nothing can stop its advance.
